*****Winter Has Come*****

Finally, this game came to Steam and I am sure many people might be puzzled why such a game with a solid manual accompanying it appeared in Steam. Is it a promo? Perhaps a conspiracy? Maybe Valve is buggy? Absolutely not! I have played the game far before it hit Steam, and I'll say it is a real deal.

Ladies and gentlemen, this game is a geniune point&click adventure game in the spirit of old Quest for Glory Series. The inspiration and some mechanics will be familiar to the people who played those games...but you will see it is actually far better then those old games. Let us see what we have in the pot.

First of all, you are playing a Heroine who was travelling to city of Fornsigtuna gets ambushed by an ettin (two-headed giant). But thanks to luck, they are unable to eliminate their target. And from there, your story of heroine-ism starts (of course, your first task is to find some food, naturally)! I should say, playing the game from Heroine perspective adds quite a spice to the game, signifying that the game will be quite different then Quest for Glory games we know.

You can choose from three different kinds of classes with their own unique approach to both main quest and side quests. As well as by buying some cross-class skills you can spice up your game even further...but do not rely on that too much. Three classes are Fighter, Mage and Thief. I would suggest you to take a glance at the manual for the explanation of skills&such which may come in handy.

The dialogues are fully voiced and there is no shortage of interesting characters...where I'd like to refrain mentioning them for the time being. But one major thing you will notice is this: When a character is at the presence of another, the dialogue lines may differ or other character can add a comment of his own...which makes the dialogue system even richer then it already is. Aside that, several minigames (wizard challenges, gambling with Fornsigtuna locals etc) add to the charm of this game.

One major point is the survival. Yes, you have to eat food to survive and on top of that you have to find a way to keep yourself warm...since it is Fimbulwinter...it is more crucial then ever. Since there are several ways to skin a cat, there are several ways to survive. By the way, as you might see the game features a solid inspiration by Norse Mythology...so prepare to meet several characters and events which has a part over there.

You will not regret playing this game. Ragnarok awaits you!

reviewText:
Imagine a old point-and-click game, now add equipment, stats and skills and you've basically got Heroine's Quest. It's hard not to recommend since it's FREE.

EDIT 2: Just finished the game. Took me 28 hours! And I didn't do everything I could since my score was only 455 out of 500.

EDIT: I've played some more so I can give a bit more indepth comments. I'm going to talk mostly about the RPG aspects since the adventure (ie: point & click) genre is pretty well known. Just think of Monkey Island or any other adventure game and add this:

There are 3 classes you can choose: Warrior, Sorceress and Rogue. Each class starts with different stats (Strength, agility e.t.c.) but also different starting skills such as Sorceress starts with Herbalism and Rogue with Sneaking. By spending 25 skill points (you start with 50) you can learn a new skill at the beginning of the game or you can increase your stats. So the warrior class can start with the magic skill which enables her to cast spells. As far as I know you can only get new skills when you start the game so if you don't know herbalism when you've started you will never know it. Which adds replayability.

Speaking of replayability. Different classes have different solutions to puzzles and side-quests. So while a Sorceress can save someone that is freezing to death in the middle of the forest by casting Flame aura on him a warrior or rogue have to find some other way to save him. I also believe you cannot do everything (side-quests, areas, puzzles) with just 1 playthrough. But each class can get a maximum of 500 points, you know those you get by solving puzzles in adventure games. Nothing to do with leveling up stats. So every class can do equally much although different things.

The leveling up mechanics work similar to Morrowind and similar games. By using a skill or attribute you have a chance of increasing it. So if you're carrying a lot or using a melee weapon in combat you have a high chance of increasing your strength.

The combat in the game is quite unique. You use the qweaf keys to attack, I am a Sorceress which means w = staff attack, e = Magic Missile, d = Flame Aura. zxc is used for dodging, z = dodge left, x = duck (uses a lot of stamina), c = dodge right. 1234 keys is used for special attacks but I don't currently have any.

The actual combat is real time and while you can't move around you have to know when to dodge and when to attack. Different enemies have different attacks obviously and they can dodge your attacks as well. While you can find a couple of silver coins or mead on a bandit don't expect them on a varg (basically a evil wolf). But if you know Animal Ken (I think) and have daggers you can skin them.

Unlike other RPGs / adventure games you can freeze to death, starve e.t.c. in this game. Yes, you actually have to eat and sleep! Depending on what skills you know how you get your food will be different. Don't expect to succeed at fishing if you don't know Animal Ken, likewise don't expect to find edible roots if you don't know herbalism.

The game also has a day / night cycle which affects where characters are, if a shop is open or not, enemies, for instance trolls get turned to stone by sunlight so if you want to find one then wait until nightfall.

Finally this is a truly free to play game. There is no microtransactions of any kind. So if this sounds like a game you would enjoy there is no reasons not to try it.

When I finally looked at the clock, it was 5:00AM in the morning, and I was still reluctant to power down the computer and go off to bed. reviewText:
Fans of the classic adventure games by Sierra will be right at home when playing this. Taking heavy inspiration from the Quest for Glory Series (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quest_for_Glory) that was released throughout the 90s the game doesn't fail to live up to it's high standards.

The story is pretty straight forward and once again pays homage to the Quest for Glory series. Like in the older title you are a hero(ine) who is suddenly stranded in a foreign land and then forced to deal with impending doom. The story takes many twists and turns along the way and is intricately crafted to keep you on your toes.

The gameplay is equally inspired. You have a choice of three character classes to chose from when you start. Each class has their own unique traits and skills. The enjoyable part is, much like the classics, each obstacle you face can usually be solved in different ways. Magic, brute strength, or sleight of hand can be used to accomplish each task differently.  Conversational options can also change the required task. This creates the chance for a varied play through and replayability.

The combat is the Quest for Glory series was never it's strong point and it's not the strongest point of this game either. It does get the job done though and isn't a turn off.

The music and sound effects and crisp and enjoyable and fits the atmosphere of the current screen well. The voice acting is excellent if somewhat varied in it's quality.

The artwork is amazing. It represents the 90s game style perfectly. Backgrounds that look like they could have been hand painted fit together well and make the world feel well put together. The sprite work is clean and well executed. The portrait pictures for the characters are interesting and give a face to what would otherwise be a handful of pixels.

All together the game is simply amazing, especially  for something that is offered for free on Steam. If you're the person who feels adventure gaming hit it's peak in the 90s and misses the feeling those games give you this one will be exactly what you want. It feels like a game that was made by Sierra in that era and simply unearthed later.

If you've never played the classics then I still recommend you give this one a shot. Then after you complete this one I recommend you check out some of classics that inspired it and run through the entire Quest for Glory series.

reviewText:
Summary: Quest for Glory in Midgard
Multiplayer: No
Completion: 16 hrs
Cards: Yes - must craft or receive boosters, buy from the market or trade to obtain
Cloud: No

The Quest for Glory series by Sierra were basically adventure games with RPG character development and combat tacked on. Imagine King's Quest but with the ability to fight foes in actual combat instead of dying every five seconds to the environment. Heroine's Quest takes much of its inspiration from these series of games and adds a few mechanics of its own.

Right away you'll notice the generous use of norse mythology, even hinted in the game's subtitle. The decision to have this set so directly in norse mythology feels somewhat odd to me. Rather than creating its own mythology that's inspired by real life mythology, this one references it directly and loosely retells those stories. It's not a bad thing - Disney does that all the time. But this one feels a tad out of place.

There's some good humor here and there. The squirrel is great. I enjoyed the Tetris game over. I feel it could use a few more laughs though. Roughly 80% of the characters are intensely serious, and they don't quite gel in a world that has silly characters like Aurvandel.

The art and music is fantastic. The game world feels somewhat barren, but this is more a fault of the genre, as many adventure games tend to include many screens with little interactivity. I would have liked more items sprinkled on the ground that you could pick up.

The hunger/survival mechanic is strange at best. Adventure games generally reward you for exploring. Heroine's Quest instead punishes you for straying too far, or taking your time. Because of the survival gimmick, the puzzle-solving seems to take a backseat because you're always pressed for food and warmth. Thankfully you can shut this feature off, but I did try to play it as intended and did not find it increased the fun factor at all.

The combat system is pretty simplistic. It's one-on-one real time combat with menu inputs, much like the QFG1-3. Nothing special, and not irritating. It's just there.

Most of the game is voice acted, which is rare for indie adventure games. Huge thumbs up for that! Most voices are good, though Hervor sounds curiously tired and disinterested. I get that there's a deadly winter, and everyone is at their wits end, but I would have liked a more likeable character to wake up to first thing than her.

The map is greatly appreciated! This also gets a huge thumbs up. That is definitely something missing from just about every adventure game.

Perhaps the most striking feature of this game is the fact that it is free! Try it out. You've got absolutely nothing to lose but time. The sheer amount of work that must have gone into it cannot be understated. I enjoyed it enough that I believe it deserves a donation. I give this game a 8/10

reviewText:
Why is this game free? I don't know. It's not a demo. There are no F2P gimmicks either. It's truly a labor of love.

So now that we got that out of the way, this is a great game. The gameplay, setting, and characters are deeply nostalgic for Quest for Glory, King's Quest, and old-school Sierra adventure game fans. The gameplay has actually taken a few modern design sensibilities to heart, adding more combat complexity and skill improvement notifications. The rich Norse setting is brought to life with colorful, interactive 2D backgrounds. While this game has a bit more text to pour through than the old Sierra games, I feel that most of the fully voice-acted characters have interesting personalities, and more conversation options are unlocked as you discover more of the world. The only thing I miss is QFG4's sardonic narrator making fun of you for trying to use a shovel on a tree--the text is there, but a voice would be more enjoyable.

I would have easily paid $20-30 bucks for this well-polished game, even though I am a miserly Steam-sale-only buyer. It must be the nostalgia factor. Rest assured, however, that if you liked Skyrim or Fallout, and you too Want To Be a Hero, there is also something mysterious and playful here to discover. Check out The Heroine's Quest, then to satisfy your appetite for more, check out Quests for Glory 1-4. QFG2 was remade, and you can download it for free here: http://www.agdinteractive.com/games/qfg2/

reviewText:
Heroine's Quest: The Herald of Ragnarok is a classic graphical adventure game themed on Norse mythology with extensive combat and RPG mechanics in the vein of Quest for Glory. It is effectively an affectionate parody of classics such as King's Quest.

Please keep in mind that although the game designers are clearly FAMILIAR with Norse mythology, this game does not simply faithfully copy it - the mythical Norse characters are noticeably different in story and/or basic design from their namesakes, which to be honest is entirely consistent with classic adventure games. For instance, it is the Heroine who goes after Fafnir at Regin's request, as opposed to Sigurd who just sits around cooking great food all day. That said, savvy players may still pick up on details ahead of time, such as with Hervor.

As the dialogue in the game is fully voice-acted, you play as the nameless Heroine who must be female and who is never referred to by name. You may select one of three classes: Warrior, Mage, or Thief. Of these three, Warrior is considered easy, Mage is medium, and Thief is hard; the game will adjust the solutions to its puzzles according to which of these classes were selected. Warrior basically just muscles and fights her way through everything, you see, and is suitable for a first play until you're familiar with the general flow of the game.

After picking a class, you are given points to boost your starting stats or add new skills - after this point, you are more or less unable to learn skills you don't already have, such as the ability to cast magic or gather herbs. I strongly advise that your first run through the game be with a vanilla Warrior with all points dumped into Agility (in my experience the slowest stat to raise).

The game is divided into several chapters, each of which makes clear a basic story goal for the Heroine to complete such as save the guy you just saw fall down half-dead in the snow". As a fair bit of warning

reviewText:
A point&click adventure with multiple possible playstyles and puzzle solutions, some combat and RPG elements and tons of optional things to do.

Upsides:
-A lot of content: it took me roughly 30 hours to beat the game on my first try (though I took my time to try and deal with every optional thing I came across). Even with so much content in a free2play game (kickstarted), the overall quality of the content is quite high. The layout is mostly non-linear so you can literally go on adventures and explore new stuff as you like. There are not only multiple ways to solve a situation/quest, but the results can vary quite a bit too.
-RPG elements: using a skill (any skill, not just combat-related) has a high chance to increase every time you use it. Even walking around aimlessly in the snow will boost your endurance and strength over time. There is also a hidden 'honour' value that is revealed at the end of the game.
-Three playable classes which can be customized even further by picking up to 2 additional starting skills. Since it's an adventure, there are obviously big similarities on what you do overall, but how you do it can be completely different. Some optional content is also genuinely reserved for certain classes / skills.
-All character dialogue is supported by voice acting.
-The music in this game is great.
-The setting (nordic mythology: odin, thor, loki, brunhild, fenrir, valkyries etc.) seems to have been taken quite seriously without diminishing the gameplay for the sake of it. The further you get into the game, the more fantasy elements you will come across.
-Day & Night cycle without any global time limit (as far as I know) so you can explore the game at your own pace. Still, the daytime can have a significant role in certain situations.

Depending on your taste:
-Trivia to other games and minor pop-culture humor (as is tradition with similar games back then I guess). However, this does not really influence the feel of the game overall (e.g. there are no 'joke' characters that belong to the actualy story etc.). Think of it as having tons of little not very meaningful eastereggs. In my oppinion, the humor is not as good as in some of the great classics, but it's nice to see how much effort they put into so many little details as well.
-Female protagonist who is not objectified (as in: the gender doesn't really influence the story, it just so happens that your character is a woman). I consider this a positive thing (I don't need huge boobies on my screen 24/7 as is the case with some other games) but you have no option to play a different (e.g. male) character, even when chosing a different class. Considering the vast amount of necessary art and voice-acting, this is quite understandable though.
-The game is quite challenging, especially at the very beginning. There are many ways to die or otherwise screw things up (even permanently!). Thankfully you can easily save and load in 50 different slots and there is also a difficulty slider. Personally, I like starting out in a creepy, hostile world and then growing more powerful in knowledge, skill and equipment. It feels like genuine accomplishments that have to be earned. Reaching a maximum score is also very difficult (there is sooo much optional content, you will not find it all on your first playthrough) so that's another motivation to try the game over with a different class.

Overall: 9/10

It's well-written and easy to control with plenty of handy keyboard shortcuts and an in-game map and player-written notebook to save you some paper. There are plenty of tongue-in-cheek references to Monty Python and QfG and lots of interesting Norse mythology to be a part of, as well as three different classes to play as.

The warmth and hunger mechanics lend some interesting new dangers to the game, making a focus on warmer clothing and hunting for food a priority as well as earning money to buy new weapons or tools.

As with any game of this style, I highly recommend saving with multiple save files. There is a single autosave slot, but that won't help you if it autosaves a mile from town with 1 health and you're freezing.

Can't wait to buy the sequels and see where we're taken next! I'm guessing from the in-game hints, we'll be heading East to a Shapier-like city a la QfG 2: Trial by Fire.

I just wanted to add my voice to the chorus of praise for this wonderful game.

I downloaded Heroine’s Quest a year or so ago from the Crystal Shard site and I can honestly say—not only does it capture the very best of what it was like to play those classic point-and-click adventures from Sierra—it was one of the most enjoyable gaming experience I’ve had in a long time.

If you loved those old-school Sierra games, you’ll enjoy this too.  It could even be argued that HQ improves upon the Quest for Glory games that clearly inspired it in a couple of aspects:  For one, it’s insanely long (in a satisfying way).  It’s got to be at least twice the length of any of the QFG’s.  Two, it seems to me there’s an even greater difference in puzzle variation depending on whether you choose to play as a thief, magic user or fighter.

The first thing people note about Heroine’s Quest is how “retro” it is.  You point and click, the character sprites roam about on fixed background rooms
date:
and the graphics are very simple.  Rather than being detriments, I think these elements are key to why this game is just so darn enjoyable.  I find such stylized characters and settings to be transporting—like that teddy bear you had as a child that you projected your own imagination onto.  There’s something in these sprites that tickles the fancy and takes you to that “cozy” place much more effectively than any uncanny-valley cutting age game could.  It’s also just cute watching these sprite-figures with their beady eyes conveying emotions; it's that same cute you get from playing LEGO games.

The old-school interface is also a plus.  This is the kind of gaming in which you’re encouraged to simply click where you want the character to go, and then observe things unfold.  It becomes this relaxing, contemplative experience in a way that your run-of-the-mill direct-control game couldn't provoke.  [In this day and age, that feels like a renegade concept.  Imagine a leisure activity that actually feels leisurely!]  In Heroine’s Quest, the sense that you’re basically just kicking back and reading a book is so strong that there were times when I was stuck on a puzzle, and frankly, I didn’t mind.  I was enjoying being stuck and simply wondering about the possibilities of what I could try next.

MINOR CONS:  I don’t have any big complaints about this game.  If you know what you’re getting into—i.e. you aren’t expecting Half-Life 3—then you'll probably enjoy it.  (And yes, it does seem necessary to add this caveat.  When you read the negative reviews, many seem to share a commonality--they're written by those whose gaming experience seems too limited to even know what subgenre Heroine's Quest harkens back to, and who seem to think that if something doesn't have the latest graphics, then it's automatically bad.)

Admittedly, Heroine’s Quest DOES have a bit of a steep learning curve.  By this I mean, when you first being playing, simply getting the Heroine to survive outside the town gates is a real challenge.  (The game takes place during an eternal winter.)  Crystal Shard perhaps should've made it clearer to the player right off the bat that finding food and staying warm would (at least initially) be a top priority--perhaps this would've minimized the number of folks who seemed to have quit HQ awfully fast before giving it a fair shake.

Well, don’t let yourself get frustrated.  Just think of it as one of the game’s “puzzles.”  In fact, I think for the first several game days you’re not even *supposed* to be able to survive for long traipsing around the woods.  (You’re going to see the, “You’re the coolest Heroine around” death pun a lot.)  It’s a challenge you have to gradually overcome.  (There are inventory items and methods you’ll discover as you progress which make standing up to the elements much easier.)

In other words, folks, please don't boot up the game for the first time and ignore all conversation and exploration, run immediately into the wilderness looking for some awesome videogame action, and then complain about why your character died so fast.

Another possible negative for some: the tongue-twisting Norse/Scandinavian sounding names with 4 consonants in a row are a bit confusing at first.  But you get used to it.  (I do recommend you keep a little notebook handy—just like we used to do with the classic adventure games.  It helps you keep the characters straight, and remember whatever “missions” you’re currently on.)

A STEAL:  Did I mention this game is, insanely, free?  If that isn’t the very definition of “bang for your buck,” I don’t know what is.  I do hope that there is a sequel to Heroine’s Quest in the future.  I would gladly pay for a second go-round.  (As it is, I made sure to make a reasonable “donation” to the Crystal Shard site when I realized how much I was enjoying the game.)  And if these guys ever want to start a Kickstarter to fund one, I can promise I'll be first in the backer line.

reviewText:
A rich, refreshing take on an old (and thought to be dead) genre of gaming.

A strong female protagonist is only the beginning of what sets this freeware apart from the other point-and-click adventures that dominated the 80's and 90's market. Along with more side quests, different classes to vary gameplay difficulty and puzzle-solving, appears the unique surivial feature. Making sure your herione remains warm and fed while out in the harsh winter adds not just realism, but a depth to gameplay, forcing the player to be at wit's end as they must explore, fight, and talk their ways out of danger within a time limit. For those who wish to play more casually however, the developers have been kind enough to allow an option to either lessen this difficulty (need for food and warmth), as well as increase it. Such loving detail has been put into each pixel of this game, from mechanics, to the art, to the music, and to the voice acting. The voice acting alone had me sold on these characters being alive, and the writing is clever and chalk full of humor to keep me amused and wanting to speak to each villager and monster throughly. Even at points, struggling and dying quite a few times, having to repeat conversations sometimes changed- much to my delight. One life I'll have a conversation in the tavern one on one, and then on a new life, another person appears for a card game, and more is added onto the conversation than before. The layers prove almost as deep as the Norse lore that the game is based around to impressive amounts.

To all of my friends I have stressed that this is a game that is worthy to play and to sink effort into. It's one not to miss and already in my top favorites of this year.

reviewText: A fun adventure game with some puzzle elements. Lots of Norse mythology.

This is a mix of the Sierra games of old (Space Quest, King's Quest) with the fighting mechanics of Sid Meier's Pirates & the rpg-level-system of Elder Scrolls (the more you use a specific trait/skill, the more that skill advances).

A typical issue with most of these adventure games is the resorting to trial-&-error need to be clicking-on-everything to progress the story. This is never an issue with the game except for only a couple of situations. This is pretty darned amazing considering the size of the game.

Writing, voice-acting, dialogues & humour are all 1st class. There is clearly a lot of research behind the study of norse folkfore to bolster the story's setting & it really shows. Characters fall into the usual tropes yet the story & story-telling is rich & vibrant with just the right amount of comical references

The puzzles & combat are rewarding & the music feels just right. The game gives you just the right amount of hints without removing the challenge. For the most part the thoughtful game design goes a long way toward making specific problems more easily resolved whilst still offering the possibility for multiple solutions (usually via the class specific's unique skill sets)

The pixel graphics are a nice touch with each sprite, backdrop & portrait boasting talent in abundance. There was never an instance where a small item or set piece had me confused as to what it represented, I only mention this because this used to be an issue with these types of games but I can gladly state that every piece is self-evident & well representative of what it portrays itself to be.

All in all I have played a lot of point n'click adventure games but this one manages to take the best aspects from the genre to make a more open experience that is sure to give the SCUMMy retro fans a fresh experience. I can easily recommend this game to fans of the genre but other gamers may get alienated by the referential humour & frustrated by the graphical throwback nature

The voice acting by itself is impressive enough to warrant trying the game. Every single dialoue line spoken by a character is voice acted, and with 280000+ words that is a lot of voice acting. Not many AAA games manage to have everything voice acted, but this free game does! Tell me this is not pure dedication.

Heroine's Quest is at first glance an homage to the old RPG/adventure games of the late 80s, early 90's. But as soon as you spend some time with it you discover that it is so much more. It is an early 90s RPG if it were made today. And from that you get all the great things from those sort of games: great story that is also funny at times, complex and interesting quests that have different ways to approach and solve them, amazing atmosphere and great dialogue. All of this in exchange for some pixel graphics, which I am not a fan of, but it is evident they spent a lot of time creating the environments and characters in the game and then even animating all of them, which is not easy to do with pixel art.

The weak side of the game is the combat which is quite simplistic and basically just pushing one button most of the time, at least at the lower difficulties. It is interesting the way combat is done in this game and it is much more involved than I expected before starting to play the game, however as I said it is lacking in complexity and would've been more fun with more combat skills. This is most evident in the first half of the game or so when you only have one combat spell (as a sorceress) and dodging left, right or back. And that is pretty much all you can do in combat for the first 5-6 hours.

Some of the puzzles/quests are also annoying to accomplish because the goals that are presented are much too vague and you need to do a lot experimentation to finish them. It doesn't help that for much of the game you will have no fast travel option, so you will have to walk through the whole forrest every time you will get an idea for how to solve a certain quest, which leads to a lot of time wasted just walking back and forth.

My single gripe was that I did not like the harsh 'warmth' meter, but if you look around, you can find things that keep you warm.  Boots, scarves, cloaks, fur pelts, or even a bottle of warm water are all things that slow the meter to a very bearable level.  Also common sense can dictate whether it's a good day to go out or not.  Snowing outside means you lose warmth faster, night makes you lose warmth as well.  If you really want, you can turn the game to easy and I believe it stops the warmth meter.  If you're curious what happens when the warmth meter runs out, you start to lose stamina.  When your stamina runs out, you start to lose health (just like Quest for Glory).  Once all meters run out, you die.  So it actually takes quite a while, and it takes longer and longer as you gain more hp and stamina.

So, at first glance, the warmth meter was annoying.  But, it's really not that bad when you progress through the game and acquire things that make it trivial.  Other than that, it is a great modern Quest for Glory homage.  There's nothing else I could say was a turn-off for me.

This is one classy game. I played Quest for Glory back in the day and this is very much an homage to the form, with modern production values--it's got voiced dialogue, for one thing. Gameplay is a mix of adventure, RPG, there's a few survival elements (you have to eat occasionally and stay too long in the frozen woods and you'll freeze to death), and combat is fairly action-game--you have to dodge the right way to avoid certain enemy attacks, and recognize their tells to hit them when it's safe. The setting's extremely Norse, and while it doesn't deal -directly- with a lot of mythology, people who know their Norse will spot all sorts of little clues and call-outs.\n\nThis is the best free game on Steam, only on Steam to get a wider audience. There's no pay-to-win, no currency, it's just a game made because a group felt it should be made. It costs nothing but the space it takes to fill it, and it's rewarding to play and rewarding to beat. Sometimes I'll fire it up just to wander around and check it out once more.

You even have the same initial option of character selection, with the possibility of learning some extra skills to personalize your character. You'll improve your skills through the game by using them. The more you use them the higher they get.

Combat is in real time, so you'll need to learn which key does what to really best your enemies.

You are going to find several quests and puzzles through the game. Some of them can be impossible to solve without being the right character class and having the right skill or spell, so don't worry too much if you can't complete all the sidequests you find.

All in all, it's a fun game. It can be seen as a game to nostalgic people like myself, but I think the story it develops can be appreciated even for new players to this old kind of gaming.

NPC wander randomly and go to places that it makes no sense for them to be. For example, I go upstairs in castle and see a barrier, blocking me from entering the wizard's room. The bartender from tavern suddenly appears, walks through the barrier, then sits in the wizard's chair. When speaking to her she has the same dialogue as if we're still in the tavern.

Talking to the wizard is a major annoyance and it's puzzling why the devs thought it would be amusing to have an npc repeat everything he says all the time. Thankfully just clicking on dialogue box allows skipping it.

On the plus side, there's alot of history and there's some attention to detail when learning about the characters. The heroine is blonde, beautiful, and brave, which is standard fare for someone out to save the world(though I suppose if she were bald, ugly, and scared of her own shadow it wouldn't work quite as well). Hopefully, once leaving town will give a better impression.

As my avatar implies, I'm a fan of the classic Quest for Glory series. I'm ashamed I didn't pick this game up earlier. It's a fantastic homage to the classics, with a great deal of love and care put into the setting and story, and I'm enjoying every minute of it. It's extremely well-polished and genuinely feels like it belongs right with the Sierra originals; the only departures it makes are beneficial changes (like adding an automap feature, and displaying stat/skill gains as they're obtained) that only enhance gameplay without spoiling anything. Its mytholical base feels right in line with the various settings of the earlier ones, and it even has the same referential humor and occasional pun that would probably be annoying in any other series but fits right in here.\n\nI simply cannot offer this one enough praise.

Heroine's Quest can be descriped as spiritual successor to Hero's Quest, a combination of point'n'click adventure with RPG system. Made by fans of such genre and released for free. It's great, giving you a world to explore as three different classes, all 'actually' having different approach, unlike other more traditional RPG games. As well as having characters with their story, many optional quest and solutions. And great music.

In other words, it's like exploring the world, not grinding, and it's a crime to have this free.

Why this game was released free is a bit mind boggling.\n\nThere's quite a lot of depth in it, especially for a point & click game. it's very clearly a labor of love!
